original_title: Sri Lanka develops new tea plucking machine
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka has developed a tea plucking machine which selects the most suitable leaves, overcoming drawbacks of earlier mechanized devices, M A Wijerathna, Head of Agronomy Tea Research Institute said.

Though hand plucking is considered the best method to get the best leaves, the Tea Research Institute had been working on plucking machines for several decades knowing that workers were moving out of the sector triggering labour shortfalls.
In 2014 a pilot project was implemented to popularize plucking devices among tea smallholders.
Though there are imported tea plucking machines they were not found to be suitable for Sri Lankan conditions.
In 2020 a machine was developed to pluck selected tea leaves.
“For that we coordinated with two firms, and two machines have been designed, and a prototype of one of those machines is in really good conditions,” Wijeratne said.
“We have already applied for the patent for that machine, and by the end of the year we will probably be able to introduce a plucking machine that only plucks selected leaves from Sri Lanka.”
Sri Lanka’s large plantations in particular have been losing labour to other sectors as younger workers move out of plantations.
Workers in Sri Lanka’s large plantations have fallen to around 115,000 by 2021 from around 255,000 in 2001, according to data released by Sri Lanka’s Planers’ Association.
In the smallholder sector employment is estimated to be 455,000 workers. (Colombo/June28/2023)
